acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 48 hours EC50=0.29mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 2004).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the absence of mortality at the highest dose of 2,000mg/kg in rat acute toxicity studies using the dermal route of exposure (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Based on the dog LC50 (4 hour inhalation) value of 0.079mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is a solid according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 (oral route) value of 132mg/kg in rat acute toxicity studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: There was no treatment-related evidence of tumor incidence observed in 2-year (rats) and 18-month (mice) carcinogenicity studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity is Category 1 and bio-accumulation is low (log Kow=2.8(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), since there was no rapidly degrading (BIOWIN), it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances with melting point of >55degC are not available (melting point: 169.7-171.0degC (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data)).

explosives.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data on the decomposition energy, though the substance contains nitro groups with its oxygen budget calculated at  -98, and decomposes at 250degC (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification is not possible due to lack of data on in vivo studies, though negative results were reported in several in vitro studies (reverse mutagenicity tests, DNA repair tests and chromosome aberration tests) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being organic compounds containing oxygen (but not chlorine and fluorine) bound to the elements other than carbon and hydrogen

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Considered non-pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures since the substance is stable to heat (up to 150degC) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data)

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: The available rat reproductive toxicity studies and rat/rabbit teratogenicity studies provide slight evidence of reduced pup viability and visceral/skeletal anomalies at doses inducing reduced body weight gains in parental animals (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)). Since it cannot be clearly demonstrated that the findings of pup effects are secondary to parental toxicity, the substance is classified into Category 2.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Stable to heat (up to 150degC) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data)

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though containing nitro groups, and being sulfonyls containing chemical groups with self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of severe irritation with effects persisting in one of six test animals after day 7, observed in rabbit eye irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)).

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Rabbit skin irritation tests yielded a mean Draize score of 0.09, suggesting little potential for irritation (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)).

skin_sensitizer.rationale: Based on negative results obtained in guinea pig skin sensitization tests using the Buehler method (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (central nervous system, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In the available rat repeated dose toxicity studies, clinical signs and symptoms including vacuolization of myelinated nervous tissue of the central nervous system, increased gamma-GTP/GOT/ bilirubin concentrations, and hypertrophy of centrolobular hepatocytes were found (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)). These effects were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: In the available rat oral studies, clinical signs and symptoms including mydriasis, abnormal gait, sedation, lacrimation, tremors and emaciation were found (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)). These effects were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.
